Hi David,

FDA requirements vary from project to project but for the 
Softw=
are development parts, they come down to outlining the
process you will fol=
low and showing that you followed it.
Of course, the actual implementation =
of the requirements
is significantly influenced by the individual the FDA 
=
assigns to examine your project.

I have worked on several projects and non=
e of them gave
the unit tests to the FDA examiners. We did indicate that
10=
0% passing unit tests were part of our development 
methodology but that's =
as far as it went. OTOH, we ran
full system acceptance tests manually and p=
rovided reports 
of them to the FDA in reproducible form - that is all
the =
inputs and outputs specified as the O.P. wants 
to do with a log. Reproduci=
ble is a watchword in this
industry.

I've heard of people automating these=
 acceptance tests
with FIT - in fact I know Ward did it for some clients.
N=
ote however that these are a different sort of 
"acceptance tests" from tho=
se we talk about in XP. In
fact, with one company, I had to come up with a =

different name for XP-style acceptance tests, since
"we have no authority =
to accept anything." :-)

It seems to me that making unit test results avai=
lable
on anything but an audit basis will lead to a lot of
project overhead=
. In many companies, the developers
have little influence over the promises=
 made to the
FDA as part of a certification plan, so it may turn
out to be =
necessary to do it at this level. But if
you can influence it to only turn =
over system,
acceptance or integration tests, life may be easier.

Charlie
